The critical angle θc is given by sin θc = 1/n.

Relation between the radius of the bright patch and the depth of the lamp: A ray that just succeeds in emerging reaches the surface at the edge of the bright patch; it makes the critical angle θc with the normal.
For the limiting ray, tan θc = r / h, where r is the radius of the circular patch on the surface.
Express tan θc in terms of n: tan θc = 1 / √(n² – 1).
Radius of the patch produced by any lamp: r = h / √(n² – 1).
Two different colours, same patch: lamp A (red) is at depth h₁, water index for red = n₁; lamp B (yellow) is at depth h₂, water index for yellow = n₂.
Because the spot seen on the surface is the same for the two colours, h₁ / √(n₁² – 1) = h₂ / √(n₂² – 1).
Area of the patch: S = π r² = π h² / (n² – 1).
Using either lamp, S = π h₁² / (n₁² – 1) = π h₂² / (n₂² – 1).
Depth of the second lamp: h₂ = h₁ √( (n₂² – 1)/(n₁² – 1) ).
Final answer: The area of the light patch produced on the water surface by either lamp is S = π h₁² / (n₁² – 1) = π h₂² / (n₂² – 1), and its radius is r = h₁ / √(n₁² – 1) = h₂ / √(n₂² – 1).
